children.name: Education/Tutoring Specific Patterns

children.docstring: - **Price-First Presentation:** Showing lowest price first anchors expectations low - **Too Many Options:** More than 4-5 options causes decision para
children.name: Anti-Patterns to Avoid

children.docstring: Most customers choose the middle option when presented with three choices: - **Low tier:** Establishes price floor, makes middle seem reasonable - **M
children.name: The Goldilocks Effect (Three-Tier Model)

children.docstring: **Principle:** First price seen establishes reference point for all subsequent prices.
children.name: Anchor Pricing Implementation

children.docstring: Current BEAM structure: - 1 Subject: Base price - 2 Subjects: 25% off 2nd (good) - 3 Subjects: 50% off 3rd (good) - 4 Subjects: 4th free (excellent) -
children.name: Multi-Subject Discount Psychology

children.docstring: Current prices ($80, $100, $120) use round numbers. Charm pricing ($79, $99, $119) can: - Feel more "calculated" and data-driven - Trigger "nine-endin
children.name: Charm Pricing Consideration

children.name: What to Compare (BEAM-Specific)

children.name: Primary CTA: "Get Your Free Diagnostic"

children.name: Friction Points to Address

children.docstring: **What goes wrong:** Too many options, sub-options, and edge cases confuse visitors **Why it happens:** Trying to accommodate every possible scenario
children.name: Pitfall 1: Over-Complicating the Value Ladder

children.docstring: **What goes wrong:** If All Access feels impossibly expensive, it doesn't anchor - it alienates **Why it happens:** Assuming higher anchor = better **
children.name: Pitfall 2: Anchor Price Too Extreme

children.docstring: **What goes wrong:** Testimonials at top of page don't influence pricing decisions **Why it happens:** "Social proof is important" without strategic p
children.name: Pitfall 3: Social Proof in Wrong Location

children.docstring: **What goes wrong:** Beautiful desktop pricing table is unusable on mobile **Why it happens:** Desktop-first design, insufficient mobile testing **How
children.name: Pitfall 4: Mobile Neglect

children.docstring: **What goes wrong:** Minimalist design leaves parents with unanswered questions **Why it happens:** "Simple pricing" interpreted as "hiding informatio
children.name: Pitfall 5: Removing Too Much Information
